Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Situation2: They organize an intensive workshop for community leaders to deeply understand and apply complex theological concepts.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow, glancing at the clock above the site office. Two minutes until the safety briefing—mandatory, no exceptions. The foreman’s voice echoed in my mind: “We start together, we finish together. No one’s above the rules.” I grabbed my hard hat, but my phone buzzed in my pocket. A message from the church council: “Pastor, the workshop is about to begin. The leaders are waiting for your guidance.” I pictured the eager faces, notebooks open, expecting me to unravel the mysteries of faith, to lead them deeper. My heart pounded. The crew needed me focused, present, a reliable teammate. The congregation needed me wise, attentive, a shepherd. I stood at the crossroads, torn between the steel and dust of the site and the sacred hush of the church hall, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding all of me, right now.
